identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/South Carolina

abstract.p: National Gallery of Art in Washington mounts exhibit, The Impressionists at Argenteuil; Brooklyn Museum of Art mounts exhibit of paintings, drawing, prunts and photographs of Maxfield Parrish; photo; international panel of curators chooses 49 artists from 23 countries to participate in 12th Biennale of Sydney, Australia, festival of contemporary art; Spoleto Festival USA offers opera, classical music, jazz, theater and dance, Charleston, SC; photo (M)

block.p: By train, the little town was but a 15-minute ride from the Gare St.-Lazare in Paris in 1871, when Claude Monet settled there. Its name was Argenteuil. In the six years Monet spent there he was often visited by his avant-garde colleagues: Boudin, Caillebotte, Manet, Renoir and Sisley. Through the years they worked in the open air, at times side by side, recording scenes in and around Argenteuil. In time its name became synonymous with the style of divided light and color that became known as Impressionism. Beginning on Sunday, more than 50 of their paintings, many rarely seen outside private collections, go on view through Aug. 20 in ''The Impressionists at Argenteuil'' at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. Information: (202) 737-4215.

By train, the little town was but a 15-minute ride from the Gare St.-Lazare in Paris in 1871, when Claude Monet settled there. Its name was Argenteuil. In the six years Monet spent there he was often visited by his avant-garde colleagues: Boudin, Caillebotte, Manet, Renoir and Sisley. Through the years they worked in the open air, at times side by side, recording scenes in and around Argenteuil. In time its name became synonymous with the style of divided light and color that became known as Impressionism. Beginning on Sunday, more than 50 of their paintings, many rarely seen outside private collections, go on view through Aug. 20 in ''The Impressionists at Argenteuil'' at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. Information: (202) 737-4215.

Maxfield Parrish bridged the worlds of high art and popular culture with book and magazine illustrations and posters that appealed to a mass audience. From Friday through Aug. 6 more than 140 paintings, drawings, prints, photographs and related materials will be assembled in ''Maxfield Parrish, 1870-1966'' at the Brooklyn Museum of Art. Described as the first critical survey of Parrish, the exhibition is organized chronologically, beginning with his work in the late 1890's and early 1900's, when he developed his vivid and singular approach to art. Information: (718) 638-5000.

The sites include the Museum of Contemporary Art, the Art Gallery of New South Wales, Customs House, Artspace and Government House. From 23 countries come 49 artists chosen by an international panel of curators to participate in the 12th Biennale of Sydney, Australia. From Friday through July 30, this festival of contemporary art in the countdown to the 2000 Sydney Olympic Games (Sept. 15 to Oct. 1) includes video, film, performance, photography and painting. Information: 011-61-2-9368-1617.

On Friday night alone these are the attractions: a new production of Verdi's ''Luisa Miller,'' Brecht's ''Mother Courage,'' the Colla Marionettes from Italy with their version of Verdi's ''Aida,'' a new production of the Bright Sheng-David Henry Hwang chamber opera ''The Silver River'' and Les Colporteurs circus. With ''Luisa Miller'' as the opening attraction, Spoleto Festival USA, offering opera, classical music, jazz, theater and dance, will be off and running through June 11 in Charleston, S.C., and environs. Information: (843) 722-2764.
